CO production has grown throughout time because of unwanted chemical reactions; therefore, the design of efficient and stable catalysts with minimal metal loading is in demand in the automobile industry for CO oxidation. Herein, density functional theory is used to study the CO oxidation mechanism on single-atom catalysts (SACs) and metal-boron centered single metal dual site catalysts (SM-DSCs). It is observed that CO oxidation could follow Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism on single-atom catalysts, such as MN4, MN3, MN2, and MN2op systems, where M is a 3d transition metal. Whereas in the case of SM-DSCs, the inclusion of Boron will make the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism possible over ER mechanism with less chance of CO poisoning. The Brønsted−Evans−Polanyi (BEP) relations are proposed (as a function of oxygen atom binding) to identify the energy barriers (Ea1 and Ea2) for the release of the first and second CO2 and O2 adsorption energies for any new SM-DSCs system. Further microkinetic model is implemented on 30 SM-DSCs and found that PtBN2op and AgBN2 SM-DSCs own best catalytic activity with high Sabatier activity and Turnover frequency for CO2 production. Hence, this work provides an approach toward the possibility of LH mechanism in the class of single-metal atom-based catalysts. Introduction Carbon monoxide (CO) is the most significant single contributor to air pollution caused by automobile exhaust. CO gas is highly poisonous, making it extremely harmful in enclosed places, where it can potentially kill people [1, 2]. The automotive industry has been studying different techniques of lowering air pollution from automobile exhausts. Therefore, catalytic oxidation of CO is considered as an important method of reducing hazardous exhaust emissions. At present, platinum group metals (PGMs) constitute the most important catalytic systems and exhibit high stability and activity for CO oxidation in the automobile industry [3–5]. However, the issue of scarcity and high cost of PGMs based catalyst, together with the issue of instability and deactivation by CO poisoning, have hindered their large-scale applications for the present and future demands [6, 7]. Rational design of catalysts requires a descriptor based approach that can be used as a guide for designing new catalyst using reactants binding energies [8, 9]. Therefore, for the design of an efficient CO oxidation catalyst, the surface must have minimal metal atom loading, a high binding affinity for O2, be resistant to self-oxidation, and have a minimal risk of reactive species poisoning. Various types of advanced catalysts are reported in literature for a more profitable use of metals in catalytic converters [10–12]. Generally, three classes of catalysts are identified for CO oxidation; noble metals (such as Pt [13], Pd [14], and Rh [15]), gold catalyst [16], and metal oxides (such as IrO2 [17]), are proven to be effective and low-cost catalyst. Recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have become a new area of focus in the field of catalysis with the lowest possible metal loading and meet the demand of industry by minimizing the requirement of PGM, also maintaining a similar degree of efficiency [18–20]. SACs can be considered as two major types (i) dispersed on the surface and (ii) embedded in the surface. The stability and long-term use of the first kind are not found to be suitable and an open question, whereas the second type SACs are stable and can exhibit good catalytic performance. In 2009, Qiao et al. prepared and characterized a practical catalyst with Pt single atoms dispersed on iron oxide (Pt@FeOx), which showed high activity for CO oxidation [21]. Similarly, other catalysts have also been used for low-temperature CO oxidation such as Pt@Al2O3 [22], Os@MgO [23], Cu@MnO2 [24], Pd@ZrO2 [25] , and Pd, Rh/CeO2 [26]. In the case of metal dispersed on surfaces, it is extremely difficult to place the metal atoms on the surface orderly and get strong binding between metal and surface [27]. The graphene-based metal SAC was fabricated by Sun et al. using the atomic layer deposition (ALD) method in 2013 [28]. Further, Lu et al. predicted theoretically that a single Au atom embedded in graphene monovacancy (Au@graphene) is a good candidate with high catalytic activity for CO oxidation [29]. The catalytic performance on non-noble metal ‘Fe’ embedded SAC is found to be comparable to that on Au1/graphene at low temperatures by Ma et al. [30]. Recently, a more confined single-atom catalyst embedded in N-doped graphene support (M-N-C; M = Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, etc.) has been demonstrated to exhibit high catalytic performance for various reactions with the possibility of tuning their activity by changing the neighboring atoms [31]. N-doped graphene can anchor metal atoms more firmly with its large surface area and high mechanical strength [32]. It has also shown good catalytic activity towards CO oxidation but preferred ER and TER mechanism [31, 33-35]. Whereas the existing metal catalyst in the industry prefers the LH mechanism for CO oxidation and is recommended over any other mechanism for practical application [36–38]. However, due to the single metal binding site in SACs for both CO and O2, the conventional LH mechanism would be difficult. T. Kropp and M. Mavrikakis reported that coadsorption of CO and O2 at the same active site is not favorable [31]. Dual atom catalysts (DACs) have also been demonstrated as an extension of SACs in order to prefer the LH mechanism for CO oxidation [39, 40]. In 2020, Wang et al. have developed Fe-Co DACs experimentally for CO oxidation, but it is difficult to precisely control the exact configuration of dual-atomic sites [41]. Luo et al. also provided mechanistic understanding of CO oxidation on non-noble metal dimer embedded graphene. They found that heteronuclear dimeric catalysts (FeCo@C6 and FeNi@C6) are more suitable catalyst than homonuclear dimer catalyst (FeFe@C6) having activation barrier 0.49 eV and 0.42 eV respectively [42]. Whereas nitrogen coordinated homonuclear DAC (FeFe@N6) showed high activity for CO oxidation with less activation barriers (0.513 eV and 0.299 eV) through ER and TER mechanism [43]. Experimentally it is found that, DACs face aggregation of metals and reconstruction of active sites during the catalytic process, which hinders the yield [39]. Recently, Wang et al. explained the role of coordinated B dopants in tailoring the activity of Fe-N4 complexes both experimentally and theoretically [44]. This has motivated us to innovate SACs with dual site to achieve LH mechanism and maintaining less metal atom loading. We proposed 30 metal-boron centered SM-DSCs for CO oxidation following LH mechanism and identified the best catalyst using BEP relations and microkinetic modeling. Whereas first, we studied the adsorption of the reactant on 32 single-atom catalysts to show the preferred mechanism. CO and O2 adsorption energy are described and correlated with εa and εb split d- orbital band center. In order to build up the BEP relation, the adsorption energy of the oxygen atom is chosen to correlate with the energy barrier for the release of first and second CO2 (Ea1 and Ea2). Based on the BEP relation, we further estimated the catalytic parameters of 12 new metal-boron centered SM-DSCs, here the input parameters are oxygen atom binding and CO adsorption energy, calculated using the DFT method. Computational details Spin-polarized density functional theory-based calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) to estimate the various parameters [45]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) within Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) functional [46] was adopted to treat the exchange-correlation interactions. Configurations were allowed to relax until the maximum force was smaller than 0.02 eV/Å with the kinetic energy cut-off of 500 eV. The van der Waals interaction has been considered using the DFT-D2 scheme [47]. The thickness of the vacuum layer was set to be 15 Å to sufficiently avoid the interactions between mirror images. The Brillouin zone was sampled using 5 × 3 × 1 k-points grids for geometry optimization and 9 × 5 × 1 k-points grids for electronic structure study. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulation was run to demonstrate the thermal stability of catalysts, in which the NVT ensemble and a time step of 1 fs were adopted. The climbing-Image Nudged Elastic Band (c-NEB) method [48] was used to search the minimum energy pathway of CO oxidation reactions. The adsorption energies (Em) of each metal atom was computed by using the following equation, (1) E m = E Me / System − E System − E Me − bulk Where, EMe/System is the total energy of the surface embedded with metal atom, ESystem is the total energy of surface without metal atom, and EMe-bulk is the total energy of the metal atom in the bulk. Here, the relative stability refers to the stability of single-atom catalysts in comparison to the bulk metals. The binding energies of metal atoms in all 32 SACs model structures are mentioned in Table S1 of supporting information. Results indicate that all the binding energies are negative which infers the high stability of single-atom catalysts. Results and discussion Adsorption studies Firstly, we studied the adsorption properties of reactants on metal-doped nitrogen coordinated (MNX) carbon catalysts (number of nitrogen X = 4, 3, 2, and 2op: opposite). These catalysts are known as single-atom catalysts (SACs). As per reported by Yang et al., there are three possible configurations of N2C2 (M/DV-N12, M/DV-N13 and M/DV-N14) in M-N-C catalysts [49]. Among these configurations M/DV-N12 (mentioned as MN2 in this work) and M/DV-N13 (mentioned as MN2op in this work) have high binding energies and formation energy of various metal atom. Thus, we considered only MN2 and MN2op system for further studies. Eight transition metals (Ti, V, Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) are taken as metal centers to make 32 model structures of host catalyst, shown in Fig. 1 (a). The adsorption energies (Ead) of each adsorbate was computed by using the following equation, (2) E ad = E adsorbed system − E system − E free molecule Where, Eadsorbed system is the total energy of surface with adsorbate, Esystem is the total energy of surface Efree molecule is the total energy of free molecule respectively. A negative adsorption energy value of reactants suggests that gas molecule adsorption on the catalyst surface is energetically favorable. Now, to find a suitable single-atom catalyst with less CO poisoning, condition I: preferably O2 binding needs to be higher than CO on metal center, condition II: not too high (> −2.5 eV) as it will limit CO2 formation [27]. Following this, we calculated the binding energy of O2 and CO molecules on the metal center for all 32-model catalysts (the values are shown in Fig. 1(b) and Fig. 1(c)). We first observed that O2 and CO do not adsorb with desirable binding (> 0.6 eV) on nearby nitrogen and carbon sites (see Fig. S1 of supporting information). TiNX and VNX surfaces (8 out of 32 host catalysts) are ruled out as O2 binds with high binding energy (> −2.5 eV) and could be the reason for hindering the formation of CO2 (Table S1 of supporting information). In most of the host surfaces of MnNX, FeNX, and CoNX, the binding of CO is higher compared to O2 on the metal center, thus they have high chances of CO poisoning during CO oxidation (Fig. 1(c) and Table S1). The reactants (particularly O2) bind weakly on NiNX and CuNX surfaces and therefore they are ineligible for CO oxidation (Table S1). CrNX surfaces are probably eligible for CO oxidation via ER mechanism since they have O2 binding higher than that of CO (see Fig. 1(b) and Fig. 1(c)). However, Deng et al. showed that CO oxidation on similar SACs (Metal Phthalocyanine) has very high activation barriers, hence not suitable for the catalytic reaction. Whereas they reported, only CoPc can be a good catalyst for CO oxidation via LH mechanism, however, the binding of the second reactant is a question in such systems [27]. T. Kropp and M. Mavrikakis also found that the coadsorption of CO and O2 at the active site on Fe/GN4-V2C type SAC is not favorable [31]. Hence, we can infer that SACs considered above are not suitable for CO oxidation, as their structures restricted them to follow the LH mechanism and failed to adhere to the above-mentioned two conditions. In our previous work, we have shown that site specific doping of heteroatoms (particularly B) on the carbon-based catalysts can facilitate the more efficient LH mechanism for CO oxidation [50, 51]. Thus, we focus on a new type of catalyst composed of metals (Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) and directly coordinated Boron (B) atom [such surfaces can be synthesized experimentally as per literature [44]], named as metal-boron centered SM-DSCs, MBNX (X = 3, 2, and 2op) (Fig. 2 (a)). Recently, Tang et al. reported that the coordinated BxNy atoms could regulate the charge transfer, stability, and reactivity of SACs [52]. We defined the binding energy of metal atom with respect to bulk metal energy and observed that the binding energy of metal atom is -ve with respect to the bulk system for all the metal-boron centered single metal dual site catalysts (see Fig. S2). Wang et al. proved experimentally that directly coordinated B dopants could help to anchor and stabilize the metal (Fe) atoms and gradually increased Fe contents on the surface from 0.75 to 1.34 wt% for FeBNC sample [44]. Now, due to dual sites (Metal and Boron) and change in the binding of a metal atom with the host surfaces in SM-DSCs (see Fig. S2), the binding strength of reactants (specifically O2) on metal increases and hence the overall mechanism for CO oxidation may vary compared to SACs. Fig. 2(b) depicts the corresponding adsorption energies of oxygen molecule on a metal atom in MBNX (X = 3, 2, and 2op) systems for the most stable configuration after optimization, and Fig. 2(c) shows adsorption energies of CO molecule on boron atom. Keeping the first two conditions in mind, we are looking forward to a catalyst for which O2 binding on metal atom should be more and CO binds strongly on B-atom without CO poisoning. Results indicate that mostly on CoBNX, NiBNX and CuBNX surfaces, O2 binding on metal is neither too low (> −0.6 eV) nor too high (< −2.5 eV) (See Fig. 2(b)). Moreover, these surfaces also have moderate CO binding on B and comparatively less than O2 binding on metal (See Fig. 2(c)). Here, we also considered the boron site for O2 adsorption but after optimization, the most stable configuration of an adsorbed oxygen molecule is coming on a metal site with almost same binding energies as on metal site for O2 adsorption. Similarly, the most stable configuration of CO adsorption is coming on the boron site. Hence, in order to check the possibility of LH pathway, we considered O2 adsorption on the metal site and CO adsorption on the boron site respectively. For more details about the binding energies of reactants, see Table 1 . Effect of boron doping d-band (εd) center for each system is then calculated in order to provide a representation of energy levels of surface that are responsible for chemisorption of reactants. While evaluating the relationship between adsorption energy of CO, O2, and d-band center, we find that neither ECO nor EO2 can be linearly fit as a function of the d-band center (See Fig. S3). By contrast, we find that splitting of d-orbital into its respective individual five d-orbitals can be used as an evaluation parameter for defining the chemisorption trends. d-orbital split into εa (band center of sum of d x 2 − y 2 and d z 2 orbitals) and εb (band center of sum of dxy, dyz, and dxz orbitals) [53, 54], here the εa band center is in higher energy level (near to Fermi level) compare to εb band center and the schematic is shown in Fig. 3 (a). The calculated εa and εb band center of metals in MNX substrate are shown in Fig. S4. We find that the adsorption energy of O2 follows the volcano plot with εa band center and exhibits goodness of fit (correlation coefficient) R2 = 0.75 and R2 = 0.74 in MNX systems, as shown in Fig. 3(b). B dopants in MBNX surfaces lead to lowering in charge transfer in-between M-B compare to M-C bond and hence more electron occupancy of εb band and shifting of εb towards Fermi level. This can be also seen in density of states where the states are shifting towards fermi level after boron doping (see Fig. S5). Thus, in the case of MBNX systems we found that both εa and εb band center correlate with EO2 with reasonable R2 value (See Fig. 3(c) ∼ (d)). It is noted that CO binds with metals via donation, back donation mechanism [55] and here also the trend is similar as the correlation with εb band center is less and has a correlation with εa band center (see Fig. S3). The O2 and CO bind with B center via charge transfer mechanism [56]. These results indicate that MNX and MBNX SACs split band centers (M = Cr, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu) might be utilized to assess whether the energy match between SACs and adsorbed small molecule is suitable, despite the fact that they rely on a variety of chemical interactions between the metal atom and adsorbates. Reaction mechanism Liu et al. investigated in their work that the strength of interaction between gas reactant and reactive supports influences the co-adsorbed species combination [57]. Wasey et al. also showed the same phenomena on h-BN/Ni (111), where they checked the simultaneous interaction of reactant molecules on the surface to define the reaction pathway [58]. Hence, in order to estimate the catalytic mechanism coadsorption of reactants needs to be checked. The co-adsorbed (CO…O2) on the surface is represented in Fig. 4(a), 4(b), where the O2 molecule is adsorbed on a metal atom and the incoming CO pulls the O atom of the O2 molecule towards itself and sits on the adjacent Boron site forming an intermediate (CO…O2). O2 bond length elongates to 1.41 Å. From charge density difference plot (See Fig. 4(c), 4(d)), we obtained more insight about intermediate (CO…O2) interaction with the surface, using following equation, (3) Δ ρ = ρ ( Int − Surf ace ) − ρ ( Surf ace ) − ρ ( Int ) , Here, ρ (Int-Surface) is the charge density of intermediate (Int) in adsorbed state, ρ (Surface) is the charge density of clean surface and ρ (Int) is the charge density of isolated molecule of intermediate (Int). Charge density difference plot is shown in Fig. 4(c) and 4(d) for NiBN3 and CuBN2 systems respectively. The blue and green lobes of isosurfaces showed the charge accumulation and charge depletion region. The isovalue is set to 0.003 e/Bohr3. It is evident that there is a high electron accumulation on BC bond, OM bond and OC bond of intermediate (CO…O2). This confirms the strong adsorption tendency of intermediate on the surface. Based on the coadsorption of reactive species, CO oxidation via LH mechanism has been considered as a model reaction to evaluate the catalytic activity of these metal-boron centered SM-DSCs. For a more detailed picture, the free energy profile of CO oxidation via LH mechanism on CuBN2 and NiBN3 is demonstrated in Fig. 5(a), 5(b). In CuBN2, the co-adsorption of reactants on the active sites forms a stable intermediate (CO…O2) on the SM-DSC surface with co-adsorption energy of −2.01 eV. First CO2 will further generate leading to an activation barrier (Ea1) of 0.72 eV. According to a previous study by D.C. young, those reactions which have barrier energy of about 0.8 eV (20 Kcal mol−1) will proceed readily even at low temperatures [59]. This indicates a high catalytic activity of metal-boron centered SM-DSCs. In the next step, the remaining oxygen molecule can be easily removed by another CO molecule to release the second CO2 with an activation barrier (Ea2) of 0.05 eV. Similar reaction pathways will be followed on NiBN3 SM-DSC also (See Fig. 5(b)). Identification of energy descriptor Further, we selected the binding energy of oxygen atom (EO) on metal as an energy descriptor of catalytic activity [60]. We defined Ea1 as the barrier energy for the release of first CO2 and Ea2 is the barrier energy for the release of the second CO2. Then, we focus on finding the Brønsted−Evans−Polanyi (BEP) relation between the EO and energy barriers (Ea1 and Ea2) considering DFT calculated 18 metal-boron centered SM-DSCs. We find that Ea1 and Ea2 are linearly correlated with EO as shown in Fig. 6 (a), 6(b) with the goodness of fitting (R2) 0.83 and 0.82 respectively. The BEP relations representing the fitting lines are given below: (4) E a 1 = 0.28 × EO + 1.35 (5) E a 2 = − 0.34 × EO − 0.63 We find out that the stronger the oxygen atom adsorption energy, the lower the Ea1 (See Fig. 6(a)) and higher the Ea2 (see Fig. 6(b)) which indicates that strong adsorption helps in the formation of first CO2 and hinder the release of second CO2. Hence, moderate adsorption of reactants is most favorable for CO oxidation. We can also estimate the correlation between EO2 and EO which can linearly fit with R2 = 0.86 by the following equation, (6) E O 2 = 1.30 × E O + 1.88 The plot is shown in Fig. 6(c). Based on the above-mentioned relationship, we can do a large-scale screening of comparable catalytic systems to find potential catalysts. The plots (Fig. 6(a), 6(b)) indicate that too strong oxygen atom adsorption leads to difficulty in CO2 desorption and too weak oxygen atom adsorption leads to difficulty in the process of CO2 formation. As a result, we may infer that EO can be an effective descriptor for energy barriers based on major linear relationships. Catalytic activity and turnover frequency According to Sabatier principle, to get a heterogeneous catalyst with high activity and efficiency, the reactant binding energy should be neither too high nor too low as high binding hinders the next reaction cycle and low binding leads to higher barrier energies [61–62]. Fig. 6(d) shows a contour plot of Turnover frequency (TOF) versus ECO and EO2 over metal-boron centered SM-DSCs to identify the catalytic activity for CO oxidation. The Sabatier activity (SA) is calculated as, (7) Activity ( SA ) = k b Tln ( R Smax h k b T ) In addition, the Turnover frequency is given by, (8) Turn over frequency ( TOF ) = lo g 10 ( R 3 + R 4 ) The detailed steps for calculating SA and TOF are given in supporting information. SA and TOF values for 18 metal-boron centered SM-DSCs are calculated using adsorption energies and barrier energies calculated by DFT calculations, more details are given in supporting information (see Table S3). Our calculated results show that CuBN2 and NiBN3 surfaces have SA of 0.54, 0.50 and TOF of −3.72 s−1, −4.40 s−1 respectively (see Table S3) at low temperature (298.1 K) and hits the eye (red region) of 2D contour plot, represented in Fig. 6(d). In the case of TOF and SA, the more +ve (or less –ve) the value, the higher it is catalytic activity [63]. Hence, CuBN2 SM-DSC shows high catalytic activity for the formation of the first CO2 via LH mechanism among the 18 systems considered in this work for initial calculations. We performed AIMD simulation for CuBN2 and NiBN3 surfaces at 400 K to examine the stability of the catalyst. As shown in Figure S6a and b, the temperature and energy of CuBN2 and NiBN3 fluctuates slightly and the structure can be maintained very well before and after AIMD. In particular, the bond length of CuB changes only 0.05 Å in CuBN2 and NiB bond length changes 0.03 Å in NiBN3, this indicates outstanding stability. Therefore, CuBN2 and NiBN3 are expected to have super thermodynamic stability during CO oxidation process. Hence, the proposed catalyst in this work can be synthesized experimentally under proper conditions and have good stability. Further, to explore the research scope, we predicted the activities of 12 new metal-boron centered SM-DSCs using the linear relationship mentioned above. We estimated values of Ea1, Ea2, and EO2 for 12 MBNX SM-DSCs (M = Ag, Au, Pd, Pt) by using oxygen binding energy. All the estimated values are given in Table S3 marked with an asterisk (*). For calculating the catalytic activity of these catalysts, initially, we need to calculate the thermodynamic parameter EO and ECO only for 12 new systems using the DFT approach. Finally, we made a contour plot considering all 30 catalysts (see Fig. 7 ). We predicted that PtBN2op and AgBN2 has SA of 0.85, 0.81 and TOF of 1.52 s−1, 0.91 s−1 and more efficient than the CuBN2 and NiBN3 catalysts for CO oxidation via LH mechanism. For more details of SA and TOF, values see Table S3. In addition, a brief review on previous works of activation energy for rate determining step (RDS) of catalyst, Sabatier activity and preferred mechanism (ER and LH) on different metal equipped catalysts such as, metal nanoparticles (NPs), Single atom catalysts (SACs), Dual atom catalysts (DACs) has been summarized in Table 2 . In order to test the effectiveness of our catalysts (SM-DSCs), we calculated SA of metal-boron centered single metal dual site catalysts following the LH mechanism and compared the results with these metal-based single and dual atom catalysts mentioned in Table 2. Results reveal that metal-boron centered SM-DSCs are highly efficient and thermodynamically favorable, and can be considered as suitable system for CO oxidation following LH mechanism. Conclusion In summary, we achieved the possibility of LH mechanism on metal-boron centered single metal dual site catalysts (SM-DSCs). The metal-boron center increases the binding energies of reactants (specifically O2) on metals (from −0.14 in CuN2 system to −0.76 eV in CuBN2 system) and B itself acts as the second site for CO adsorption with −1.03 eV binding energy without CO poisoning. The chemisorption trends of reactants are better described through orbital specific analysis and split band center is reported as the electronic descriptor. Considering the binding energy of oxygen atom (EO) as energy descriptor, linear BEP relationship between EO2, Ea1, and Ea2 is built up with high R2 values of 0.86, 0.83, and 0.82 respectively, to predict new SM-DSCs for CO oxidation proceeded through LH mechanism. Through screening of 30 SM-DSCs, we concluded that PtBN2op and AgBN2 catalysts are the most efficient metal-boron centered SM-DSCs with high CO2 production rate and are worthy to do further experimental and theoretical research. Overall, this work provides a new direction to design the efficient dual site catalyst for CO Oxidation and has the potential to replace the high metal loaded catalyst in a low loaded catalyst for a cost-effective and environmental friendly solution. coredata.dc:description: CO production has grown throughout time because of unwanted chemical reactions; therefore, the design of efficient and stable catalysts with minimal metal loading is in demand in the automobile industry for CO oxidation. Herein, density functional theory is used to study the CO oxidation mechanism on single-atom catalysts (SACs) and metal-boron centered single metal dual site catalysts (SM-DSCs). It is observed that CO oxidation could follow Eley-Rideal (ER) mechanism on single-atom catalysts, such as MN4, MN3, MN2, and MN2op systems, where M is a 3d transition metal. Whereas in the case of SM-DSCs, the inclusion of Boron will make the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) mechanism possible over ER mechanism with less chance of CO poisoning. The Brønsted−Evans−Polanyi (BEP) relations are proposed (as a function of oxygen atom binding) to identify the energy barriers (Ea1 and Ea2) for the release of the first and second CO2 and O2 adsorption energies for any new SM-DSCs system. Further microkinetic model is implemented on 30 SM-DSCs and found that PtBN2op and AgBN2 SM-DSCs own best catalytic activity with high Sabatier activity and Turnover frequency for CO2 production. Hence, this work provides an approach toward the possibility of LH mechanism in the class of single-metal atom-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: First-principles identification of CO oxidation via LH mechanism over ER mechanism on metal-boron centered single-metal dual site catalyst
